description.narrative: IDI's vision, and hence the contribution's overall objective, is: Effective public external audit by Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) promotes transparency and accountability, effective public financial management, good governance, improved service delivery, fights corruption and contributes to poverty reduction and sustainable development. The vision is followed by a mission-statement, core-principles and four objectives with three intermediate objectives each. These objectives are all clearly linked to performance-indicators, outputs, outcomes and impact as well as to baselines and targets. The four objectives constitute "work streams", meaning that IDI works with these areas continuously and not only as program objectives to be achieved over a short period of time. The four objectives are: Independent SAIs, Well governed SAIs, Professional SAIs and Relevant SAIs.

INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI) hereby applies for a continued core support for its new Strategic Plan 2019-2023, for the period 1 January 2019- 31 December 2019. The applied total amount is 75 000 000 SEK, amounting to 12-14 % of IDI’s total budget for the entire Strategic Plan.
The International Organisation for Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) is a non-profit umbrella organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (SAI) across the world with 194-member countries. INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI) is a non-profit, autonomous INTOSAI body, mandated to support SAI's in developing countries to sustainably enhance their performance and capacity. The IDI also serves as secretariat to the INTOSAI-Donor Cooperation. IDI was established in 1986 as an INTOSAI training body, and is currently located in Oslo, Norway. IDI receives a significant portion of its core funding based on an Act of the Norwegian Parliament, passed when IDI was transferred to Norway in 2001, where it is established under Norwegian Foundation Law. Except Norway, other core support donors are (Sweden), Austria, Estonia, DFID, European Commission and INTOSAI. A number of donors with earmarked-support are i.e. France, Canada, Saudi Arabia, Iceland.
IDI has presented a more ambitious Strategic Plan for 2019-2023. The increased ambition lies in a new working method, so-called work streams with a new results matrix, increased focus on quality in the capacity development and increased focus on support and a full integration of gender mainstreaming throughout the Strategic Plan; from gender analysis of specific projects to gender mainstreamed activities and gender-mainstreamed selection of participants, trainers and workplans.
IDIs Strategic Plan aims at capacity strengthening of the Supreme Audit Institutions (SAI’s) in developing countries and in fragile countries through need-based and locally anchored programmes involving trainings, technical support and organisational development. Sida assesses IDI to have the mandate, expertise, systems, networks and long-term experience of conducting capacity development programmes of SAI’s in developing countries, and can therefor contribute to rule of law through its contribution to increased transparency, accountability, and improved service delivery, benefiting all citizens, and mostly the most poor.

Insatsen avser ett kärnstöd till den internationella organisationen för riksrevisioner, the International Organisation for Supreme Audit Institutions, INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI), om totalt 75 000 000 SEK under en fem års-period med startdatum 1 januari 2019 till och med 31 december 2023. Insatsen syftar till att kapacitetstärka riksrevisioner i utvecklingsländer genom ett behovs- och efterfrågansbaserat arbete bestående av utbildningar, informationsspridning och tekniskt stöd.
INTOSAI är en icke-vinstdrivande paraplyorganisation för riksrevisioner över hela världen. INTOSAI har 194 medlemsländer och ar en regional organisationsstruktur med underorganisationer och diverse kommittér och arbetsgrupper. INTOSAI har ett kapacitetsutvecklingsorgan; INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI) som är registrerad som en separat enhet och är icke-vinstdrivande organisation. IDI har haft kärnstöd från Sida de senaste 15 åren och de har härmed inkommit med en ny ansökan om förnyat kärnstöd om 75 000 000 SEK som täcker perioden för IDI's nya strategiska plan, 2019-2023. Den totala budgeten för IDI 2019-2023 är ca 579 228 196 SEK, det föreslagna Sida stödet om 75 000 000 uppgår till ca 12-14 % av den totala budgeten. Det innebär en procentuell minskning från föregående kärnstödperiod - 2014-2018, då den totala IDI budgeten uppgick till ca 220 000 000 SEK - då Sida stödet uppgick till ca 18%. Den procentuella minskningen, trots den stora totala budgetökningen, härleds till utökat stöd från traditionella givare samt nyförvärv av nya givare. Kärnstödsgivarna är i följande storleksordning; Norge, Sverige/Sida, Österrike, Estland, DFID, Europeiska Kommissionen samt INTOSAI. Bland givare med öronmärkt stöd finns t ex; Frankrike, Canada, Saudi Arabien, Island m.fl.
IDI bedöms av Sida ha mandat, kompetens i form av expertis, system, nätverk och erfarenhet att bedriva ett kapacitetsutvecklande program av riksrevisioner i utvecklingsländer i syfte att bidra till de svenska prioriteringarna och till att rättsstatens principer i högre grad kan råda i de kontexter programmen verkar i.
IDI har en ny och mer ambitiös strategisk plan för 2019-2023. Den ökade ambitionen består av en ny arbetsmodell med mer fokus på kvalité och stöd, anpassade efter lokala behov och rekommendationer från en halvtidsöversyn genomförd av Sida. Den ökande ambitionen består även av en genderintegration av hela den strategiska planen, från genderanalys av samtliga insatser och aktiviteter till genomförande och urval av aktiviteter, deltagare, föreläsare och arbetsplaner.

16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

description.narrative:
IDI has submitted an extensive report with an even longer appendix. The appendix is a detailed account for all activities during 2019 whereas the main report is an attempt to highlight the main achievements in terms of results for 2019. It is Sida's overall assessment that the report is still a very output oriented product but there are attempts to show results on a higher level.
Given that this is the first year of the program period, IDI is not expected to reach concrete and sustainable results based on the new strategic plan already at this point; however, given that IDI has worked for a long time with SAIs and is an appreciated partner and resource, it is likely that some results and positive impact can be reached based on the foundation and development built over the years.
IDI has recently reported its first year of activities 2019 and have a lengthy report with an even longer appendix specifying all activities. It is sometimes not easy to get an overview of progress made with such a detailed reporting. Nevertheless, IDI highlights a number of achievements in the last report. It is Sida's view that IDI has a tendency to report on activities and outputs rather than results in the sense we would prefer. This is understandable but it needs to be repeatedly raised in the dialogue with IDI that Sida appreciates efforts to report achievements on outcome level.
IDI has reached many of the world's SAIs during 2019, confirming the global caracther of the organisation. IDI reports that 166 SAIs were supported by IDI activities, of which 120 developing countries SAIs. Approximately 1900 SAI staff individuals were reached.
One of the most important features of an SAI is the independence from the executive (and other undue influence). In the dedicated work stream for SAI independence, IDI has assisted a number of SAIs to advocate for independence, as well as supporting one individual SAI in strengthening its practical independence. IDI has developed a knowledge centre and an online platform to provide support on independence issues and tried to set up a 'rapid advocacy mechanism' for SAIs whose independence is threatened. In the INTOSAI-donor cooperation (where Sida is a part) IDI tried to mobilise support for a joint donor statement for two countries where the SAIs were threatened by measures from the executive to limit their independence. When Sida discussed the issue with foreign representations in the countries concerned it was decided that Sweden would prefer a response from the country representatives regarding all public institutions at risk, in certain cases also including the threats to CSOs and free media. Some donor colleagues in the INTOSAI-donor cooperation will likely face similar challenges, which is a limitation to the effectiveness of such a rapid advocacy mechanism. The audit office is often not the only institution that is under attack during unrestful times; and partner countries with country representation are often eager to coordinate its response from there.
A big piece for IDI when it comes to well-governed SAIs is the SAI Performance Measurement Framework that is developed based on other assessment tools such as the PEFA tool for PFM systems. PMF is a measurement tool for SAIs to use as an indication of its own development. It is not thought to be a benchmark to other peer institutions but it may unavoidably be used in that way, which of course has both pro's and con's. 11 SAI PMF were finalised in 2019 and so far 57 countries have undergone the assessment to identify performance in a number of areas such as audit quality and quality assurance systems.
Regarding the professionalisation of SAIs, IDI has developed handbooks for both financial and compliance audit. It is too soon to note any impact of these handbooks even if they have been published in multiple languages. It is also not very clear how these products relate to the handbooks already in place in individual countries as well as the connection to other development initiatives by other actors or provider of support. Given that the quality is good, it is of course very positive that the handbooks are available to any SAI who needs them. It will be interesting to hear how the handbooks have been received by the SAI community.
In an effort to make SAIs relevant to their national stakeholders, IDI has supported more than 50 SAIs in their audit of the respective government's implementation of the SDGs. Also this effort needs to be followed up at a later stage to see t owhat extent it has had any effect on a ational level.
IDI is also a bilateral partner to the audit offices of Somalia and South Sudan. It is the board's ambition to keep IDI's bilateral engagements to a minimum and on a basis of 'provider of last resort'. This is something that also the Swedish National Audit Office has promoted through its board presence (Auditor General Helena Lindberg is a board member). This goes well in line with Sida's basis for support to IDI as an international organisation with a global added value.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
